title: Perspectives emerging from R&D in Europe

author: Žiga Turk, Ministrstvo za izobraževanje, znanost, kulturo in šport Republike Slovenije

segmentation: Thank you very much for these kind words.
Ladies and gentlemen.
Welcome in Slovenia.
I would like to welcome you on behalf of.

The Slovenian government, on behalf of the Slovenian Presidency of the EU, indeed for Internet, is close to our hearts, to the hearts of many of us, because if you know little bits of history of Slovenia, the introduction of the Internet and the making of the independent state somehow coincided temporarily.
I still remember when there was an attack on Slovenia when there were tanks of Yugoslav Army rolling on the on the streets of Slovenia.
People were using the Internet.
Or was it decnet at the time and vixen these networks?
To send out emails and messages to colleagues around the world to do something about it and just 17 years later, you see miracles are possible.
This country that did not exist at that time is now.
At the at the steering wheel of the European Union.

What I'd like to do in this brief introduction is talk a little bit about the past, present and future of Europe and how this is related to the Internet, and I'll speak mostly about the past because fast doesn't change much and I can recycle these slides over and over again while the future keeps keeps moving.
Very quickly in my professional career, I was lecturing design communication.
This is a topic which deals with, well, how do you communicate about design about designing buildings?
I'm a structural engineer by profession, and there are some nice messages that you can draw from the history of from the history of architecture and engineering.
Still today, if we have a if a country has a lot of money, if the bank has a lot of money, they tried to build some magnificent building and they put all their knowledge into that building.

And at about year 500 the most important, the most powerful empire, at least in the Western world was the Eastern Roman Empire, with a capital in Constantinople and they decided to build a magnificent.
Church there and what is really difficult about making buildings about building churches is to spend a big big area to cover a big area to make big domes too.
Create big empty spaces with the roof, of course, and they managed to do 31 meters in diameter and it broke down many times and by trial and error this somehow made it stand.
And Interestingly, if you would look at the history of architecture, not much would happen for the next 1000 years.
Again, 1000 years later the same city was a capital of the most powerful country in the region.
At the time, again, they were pouring money into into buildings into construction, and they did.
About a kilometer away from the from the.
Ayasofya they build this Soleimani mosque and they managed 26 meters in diameter so nothing really changed.
Maybe the the architecture is a little bit more elegant is not as massive as you would see with our software, but from the engineering perspective.
No big progress.
But then.
Not not very far away.
Not in time.
Not in.
Not in distance.
Saint Peters in Rome, much bigger 42 meters in diameter.
It was standing and 42 meters in.
In a ratio to 31 meters, it's not just one third better.
This goes by the square root by the square of it, so it's almost double.
Doubled up the difference.
What really happened?
In this short period of time, what made this difference?
What made this?
Possible and I'm getting to the to the story that we want to talk about the story of the Internet and the story of communication.
If you look at communication technology that was available to mankind until basically 1500s.
Writing has been invented.
Paper was there.
Peppers was there parchment was there.
In Europe.
The point I'm trying to make is this parchment was available for very very selected type of uses.
We probably all watched the movie The name of the Rose with the monks copying the Bible and the Greek classic and so on.
To the to the precious parchment paper and to these precious books.
The communication technology available at the time was only available to the very selected people for a very selected content, so it was only available for Aristotle for plateau and for the Bible.
Enter that.

Not much else at about 1200 and something Phoebe and Archie wrote the first mathematical model mathematical book with Roman numerals with Arabic numerals, introducing Arabic numerals and quite a few other things.
It was copied manually.
It took centuries literally.
For the.
This knowledge to spread around Europe and what happened afterwards was a kind of a wave of globalization.
We are now a little bit afraid of what globalization is bringing, but globalization open up some travels between Europe and China and it opened up Europe.
Too many of the Chinese inventions, including spaghetti, including ice cream including guns including gunpowder and including a cheap way of manufacturing paper.
And this really made in my view.
Significant difference all in a sudden paper.
At that time, paper communication technology was available for just about anything you want it will it became cheap, intelligent people were starting to make drawing sketches.
They were able to use paper to communicate with each other so that the architect or the master builder builder did not have to be present on the construction site.
Indeed, it was the primantis first first sketch of the Saint Peters.
Saint Peters had many architects.
Premanta was the first one of them.
This was the 1st.
Technical drawing that we have that we still have today.

The first drawing that was made to scale that was a type of technical drawing that we use today to do designs and he could draw this and think he could move onto another project and people on the side would.
Somehow go about and and make sure that the building is built according to this.
According to these designs.
So what we can say is we are speaking today a lot about this E business or anything type of revolution.
Indeed, communication today's electronic.
But what happened in Europe between 14th 15th century Wasapi?
What I call a P business revolution paper.
Business revolutions.
Paper was starting to be used as a communication media and it's this communication level.
Ocean really made a difference for European culture for European science for European economy.
In parallel to the cheap way of creating paper, Europe had this lucky circumstance of having letter based letter based writing.
This enabled printing and printing who really enabled the dissemination of knowledge.
Rapid communication from one place to the other and it was this invention of paper.
In my view, that starts the modern age is not the discovery of America.
It's the discovery of paper discovery of print.
And the paper communication technology.
The print communication technology somehow related the foundation of the outside European dominance in science and technology in culture for the next.
500 years.
So to create a chart very briefly, you don't have much much of a difference paper.
Yes, it was available, but it was not democratically available to everybody for everything.
And if communication technology is not progressing, you don't have progress in any other fields.

And the parallel that is striking between what happened 500 years ago and what is happening now is that today another type of communication, technology, electronic communication technology, Internet communication, is becoming broadly available.
We did have electronic communication 100 years ago.
We could transmit pictures from the moon.
14 thirty 40 years ago.
But it was not available for everybody today.
You can translate the picture of the same quality that the picture we were getting from the from the landing on the moon.
You can get it from any web Cam to any computer.
Anybody can do it.
It's broadly available.
It's Democratic and this is what makes a difference.
For SoC 4 four.
Technology etc etc.

So it's this democratization of technology that that makes a difference, and the impact that the paper communication revolution had 500 years ago is probably compareable to the impact that the Internet communication revolution is has on the on.
The current situation today impact.
It's of course on all.
On all areas of of living Internet is the somehow the keyword.
Of this of this second revolution, it has a major Academy Ager impact on globalization.

If you look at what the vectors are and I'm getting to more political subjects of Lisbon Strategy and thinks Europe is is doing also under the Slovenian Presidency to respond to these challenges, the impact on globalization is very much related to the Internet.
If you look at what is powering globalization, why globalization is possible?
It's of course the freedom of politics, the fall of the Berlin Wall, and are in curtain etc etc.
It is the freedom of trade, so ability to trade freely with not too excessive customs.

Among countries and technically it's supported by the advances in logistics, both of goods logistics of goods in the big cargo ships, container ships in the fast Courier services like DHL or UPS and also the logistics of information in the terms of the Internet, mobile phones etc etc.
The problem that Europe has just as a footnote with globalization, is that if you look at these drivers, if you look at politics, trade, logistics.
Who were really European politicians or the European companies driving these these things?
I don't think that.
Most of these of these issues, Europe was a driver.
It was more like.
A.
Like a follower.
Globalization somehow, or the freedom in politics somehow coincided with the.
With this information revolution in the late 1980s, early 1990s, and my theory is that somehow these things go go hand in hand.
The communication that is possible among people.
The communication technology that is available determines how you can, how you can organize a country, how you can run a country if you have just talk.
If you can just talk to each other.
Well, you can assemble people on some square like the Greeks deeds or in some form like the Romans did, but it's a fairly small group of people that has to run the show.
It's the smaller the group of people that can get together in a room.
And make a decision and this course for kind of authoritarian systems.
If you have writing.
If you have press then you can create all this bureaucracy with heaps and heaps of papers which are being pushed from one place to the other and this creates a type of representative democracy.
That we used to live in or that we live in still today.

And if you look at the modern communication technologies such as the Internet, this again broadens the number of people that can take parking decision-making decision-making, or in professional decisions and cause for a broader participation of the people.

And part of the reason that the changes happened in the early 1990s is that somehow the autocratic regimes of the Eastern Europe were somehow two generations behind the communication technology that was available.
At the time.
We used to look at the Internet and the electronic communication for a long time as a kind of one way St.
It was very much like paper, except that you didn't have to put it on paper.
You would get it on your screen.
Even the governments got organized.
In this way they enable their.
They open up their services to the citizens there, made their information publicly available.
By the way, the Slovenian governments, egovernment solutions or the services that the government is providing to the.
To the citizen and to the businesses were rated by Capgemini as the second best in Europe.
So it's a fairly well developed country in this respect.

But it's a replacement of paper, so instead of having to go to a library or to an office to get some information to get some document, you get it on the Internet instead of taking the paper to some to some to some window somewhere at the to some clerk somewhere.
The government office.
You do it electronically.
Through the Internet.
But it's still a type of one way one way.
A type of type of interaction.
What has happened in the last 10 years or so?
Maybe just after the year 2000?
Was this so called Web 2.0 type of movement which you know much better than I do?
But the keyword here is participation, so it's not one way communication.
It's not one way of dissemination of things.
It's allowing this technology to bring masses at masses of people.
Into very different processes into creative process is into innovation processes into creating standards.
So on and so on.

And this is really the most important part of the Internet revolution, as in the paper revolution 500 years ago you would give this the fact that so many more people have the communication technology available to them.
They could become Creative Day could contribute their brain their ideas into the progress of the mankind.
And we are.
Putting all this to an even higher standard, we're making this even more broadly available, and even at A at a faster.
Speed.
So where does the Web 2.0 meet the Lisbon Strategy 2.1 first wireless mouse Strategy 2.1 lisman strategy is not something that is commonly known to people from the street or two professionals.
If you're doing you project proposals, it's usually useful to sprinkle these political terms.
There at.
Appropriate places in the year 2000.
Europe says we need a strategy to catch up with Japan and US and started with this strategy 2005, we discovered that we are failing.
It was renewed by the Boroughs Commission.
It was not so much about competition with US and Japan anymore.
It was about creating growth and jobs an in 2008 few weeks ago mid March, the updated list with strategy was launched under the Slovenian Presidency.

And it became aware of many of the things that I was speaking about about the need for open innovation, open creativity, and of course not so much in our mind are the US and Japan what we're thinking about is how to tackle what is happening in China.
What is happening in India?
There are four pillars in the Lisbon Strategy.
It's about making Europe more dynamic, creative, entrepreneurial market driven economy on one hand on the other account.
Keeping this traditional European care for people and European care for nature in a kind of a balance.
To reach these goals.
How does melisma strategy respond to communication revolutions?
If you?
What has to be fairly fairly realistic about what can past layers and layers of different bureaucracies?
What kind of language can be inserted into a document which in the end is adopted by the 27 presidents or prime ministers of the Member States of the European Union?
You cannot speak really about Web 2.0 and about any 2 two big buzzwords, but still somehow it's possible to make the document.
With this strategy aware what is going on out there?

In the four pillars, the number one, the number one topic, the topic on which Europe is trying to rest its future growth and glory is innovation is the brains of the Europeans and what has been added in this update.
This year we're not speaking about innovation, only, not only not speaking about innovation of a few, but the creativity of many Europeans.
And this is what Web 2.0 and related Internet technology allow you to do.

It is introducing knowledge as the Fifth Freedom, so the freedom of Movement of knowledge in Europe, not only the knowledge in the heads of the people, but also the knowledge according to or related to the patterns of open innovation.
Of open standards of Open Access to knowledge.
Slovenia was pushing very strongly to lift the infrastructure that Europe casts with respect to broadband access.
And there is a very specific conclusion that asks for all European Member States to make sure that all schools have broadband access by 2010.
And to Preneurship and Internet or Internet economy related issues, more competition in network industries.
Single European market.
Cross border interoperable solutions for electronic signature and key authentification.
And there are some other issues which also relates to Internet.
I think the big the big topic in European scientific and all other policies will be climate change energy.
The set plan.
Is the set plan strategic Energy Technologies plan is also calling for smart grids?
It's calling for solutions where the type of Democratic production of energy meets the communication possibilities of the Internet to make this Democratic production of the energy.
Possible.
Specifically on infrastructure, what the presidents prime Ministers decided is that the infrastructure and I high speed Internet usage must be significantly increased.
I don't think it's a big secret that Slovenian Presidency was was aiming for a specific numerical targets, but it did not pass.
It did not.
Possible to reach a consensus among the leaders in Europe, but this very clear target remained the schools we have to we want to make sure that the kids in schools have them.
Infrastructure that is needed.

I was speaking already about the Fifth Freedom and how important it is to look at it, not just the movement of people but also the movement of knowledge in the sense of openness into the sense of open innovation in the sense of supporting this type of innovation that many companies are nice now.
Subscribing to that.
In fact, maybe the best ideas are outside of the R&D facility of that company that the best ideas are with the users.
For the best ideas would come just from about everywhere and This is why you have to open up your innovation.
Turns to include include these guys kinds of people and to do so you have to be open with the knowledge that you are creating.
You have to share your knowledge openly.
You have to be.
Based on open standards.
So in summary, communication, revolution, change code revolutions changed the way we live together.
We work together how we innovate.
They even are changing the political process.
They allow for much broader participation of the many and we are in the middle of such a revolution.
It's far from being over.
I think what is extremely important is that the Internet is allowing more talents to take part in creativity and innovation.
You kept you can bring more brains into the picture and given the competition that we have from India from China, we have to make sure that we make the best use of all the brains that we have here.
The businesses are taking note about this for long long time.

I think the governments the politicians are trying to take notes as well and the updated list of strategies taking note as well the research and development is far from over and I hope this conference will.
That come up with some answers and with many more new challenges, so I wish you all the best.
In bed and and in.
Teresting event.
Thank you.
